svg.style: background: transparent; background-color: transparent; color-scheme: light dark;

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 388px; height: 1px; padding-top: 80px; margin-left: 261px;

div.p: ARP stands for Address Resolution Protocol. It's a fundamental networking protocol that acts as a "translator" between IP addresses (Layer 3, logical addressing for routing across networks) and MAC addresses (Layer 2, physical addressing for local delivery on a network segment).

switch.text: ARP stands for Address Resolution Protocol. It's a fundamental ne...

div.p: 1. Device A,will creates an ARP packet: "Who has IP 192.168.1.20? Tell Target IP 192.168.1.10."

switch.text: 1. Device A,will creates an ARP packe...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 220px; height: 1px; padding-top: 995px; margin-left: 286px;

div.p: 2. Encapsulates it in an Ethernet frame: Source MAC = A's MAC; Destination MAC = Broadcast (FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF—all 1s, floods the LAN).
ARP requests are 28-byte payloads inside an Ethernet frame (64 bytes total)

switch.text: 2. Encapsulates it in an Ethernet fra...

div.p:
"IP 192.168.1.20 is at MAC 77:88:99:AA:BB:CC."
(Source: B's IP/MAC; Target: A's IP/MAC—no broadcast here for efficiency.)

div.p: 1. And on each device, every network interface receives it too, Because destination MAC address is set to FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF (the universal "everyone address")

switch.text: 1. And on each device, every network interface receives it too...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 370px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1820px; margin-left: 211px;

p.font: 2. device cannot ignore them because broadcast frames are addressed to FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF, which all NICs are designed to accept.

switch.text: 2. device cannot ignore them because broadcast frames are add...
